text: The New York firm, founded by Gabe Plotkin, a protégé of Point72 founder Steve Cohen, was forced earlier this week to seek a $2.75bn cash injection from its larger rivals Citadel and Point72, after it had lost about $3.75bn, or 30 per cent, in the first three weeks of the year, according to two people familiar with the matter.

elements.text: The New York firm, founded by Gabe Plotkin, a protégé of Point72 founder Steve Cohen, was forced earlier this week to seek a $2.75bn cash injection from its larger rivals Citadel and Point72, after it had lost about $3.75bn, or 30 per cent, in the first three weeks of the year, according to two people familiar with the matter.

text: I’m looking to develop some algorithmic trading strategies for financial markets but suffering from a bit of information overload about where to start. I know there’s a few finance guys on here so any recommendations for software packages for backtesting, affordable but decent data sources, and any essential reading for a retail quant?

elements.text: I’m looking to develop some algorithmic trading strategies for financial markets but suffering from a bit of information overload about where to start. I know there’s a few finance guys on here so any recommendations for software packages for backtesting, affordable but decent data sources, and any essential reading for a retail quant?

text: Interactive brokers is pretty much the only broker option for a retail client - they have an API

elements.text: Interactive brokers is pretty much the only broker option for a retail client - they have an API

text: Yeah that’s pretty much the only thing I’ve managed to work out :joy:

elements.text: Yeah that’s pretty much the only thing I’ve managed to work out

text: Try deciding asset class first too. They all have quirks. Equities are familiar to most, but have a lot more quirks than most expect (corporate actions are a pain)

elements.text: Try deciding asset class first too. They all have quirks. Equities are familiar to most, but have a lot more quirks than most expect (corporate actions are a pain)

text: You will also need to decide this because there's varying tax implications depending on the asset class and domicile of the products

text: First tip if you go down this route is to get hold of some intraday data, even a daily model should try and avoid using the closing prices - they're not executable, they're marked from a closing auction which isn't a price you can be certain to get

text:
IG Index have an API too (streaming for Indices & commodities + equities on request) and REST for everything else.

The tax implications are probably more relevant for financial markets, plus of course leverage (i.e. do you self declare as a professional and get greater leverage but lose guaranteed stop loss protection, for example).

elements.text:
IG Index have an API too (streaming for Indices & commodities + equities on request) and REST for everything else.

The tax implications are probably more relevant for financial markets, plus of course leverage (i.e. do you self declare as a professional and get greater leverage but lose guaranteed stop loss protection, for example).

text: Re asset class for retail quant, I would recommend to steer clear of CME and EUREX futures trading. They are extremely deterministic and dominated by < 5 players for delta one strats. If you know about options, then your space opens up significantly as options trading (especially delta neutral strats) are more about modelling than execution speed. Look at more niche sectors, for example agricultural products, Chinese products, LME metals. I am not sure about market access for those at the retail level though.

elements.text: Re asset class for retail quant, I would recommend to steer clear of CME and EUREX futures trading. They are extremely deterministic and dominated by < 5 players for delta one strats. If you know about options, then your space opens up significantly as options trading (especially delta neutral strats) are more about modelling than execution speed. Look at more niche sectors, for example agricultural products, Chinese products, LME metals. I am not sure about market access for those at the retail level though.

text: I used OANDA many years ago, but didn't get very far with it. I'm good at stock trading but generally over weeks/months, so decided that automating wasn't worth the effort. Having spoken to lots of Forex traders over the years, they generally seem to share the opinion that trading sports is easier.

elements.text: I used OANDA many years ago, but didn't get very far with it. I'm good at stock trading but generally over weeks/months, so decided that automating wasn't worth the effort. Having spoken to lots of Forex traders over the years, they generally seem to share the opinion that trading sports is easier.

text: You can do some pretty simple maths to work out roughly what an options price should be, and I’m sure this applies to other assets too, but a load of exchanges have “speed bumps” so you can put up prices, and then if the underlying moves against you the aggressive orders face a 250 ms (or whatever) delay, so even though you’re up against people who are colocated running FPGAs, you can still get out of the way running a simple python bot over the internet.
